title: Node unable to sync
body:
I'm running a dockerized nethermind node. My block and state syncing is at 100%, but branch syncing never crosses 80-85% and it resumes state sync. Some logs from the node for reference:

```
2021-10-05 09:22:22.2851|State Sync 00.18:21:26 | ~100.00 % | 74554.42MB / ~72520.00MB | branches: 83.98 % | kB/s:   274 | accounts 148322623 | nodes 871524393 | diagnostics: 16.485.41ms 
2021-10-05 09:22:22.6905|Branch sync progress (do not extrapolate): 84.38 % of block 13358087

2021-10-05 09:22:23.4812|Setting state sync state root to 13358087 0x233d30abe3d66308c30d256cb8a3c2125d73197c2d553af138daf8f72c68410c

2021-10-05 09:22:35.1377|State Sync 00.18:21:36 | ~100.00 % | 74554.50MB / ~72520.00MB | branches: 0.00 % | kB/s:     0 | accounts 148322624 | nodes 871524713 | diagnostics: 7.482.53ms 
2021-10-05 09:22:36.3646|Changing state StateNodes to FastSync, StateNodes at processed:0|state:0|block:13357029|header:13358245|peer block:13358249 
2021-10-05 09:22:36.3646|Sync mode changed from StateNodes to FastSync, StateNodes 
```

The documentation does point out that this may happen. But it doesn't provide any solution for this. I'm running this on the cloud and it's got more CPU/Momory and disk IOPS and Throughput available than it uses. How can I get past this?

I'm running on the following instance:
c6g.2xlarge - 8 vCPU, 16GB RAM,
gp3 volume - 420 GB - 12000 IOPS, 500MB/s throughput

Could memory be insufficient for cache? CPU surely is not the bottleneck, and disk doesn't seem to be either (checked with iostat)
Ignore the above, took a while but it synced after a few minutes

Reopening issue:

Node is stuck at Receipt Download:

```
2021-10-05 14:27:26.3493|Discovered new block 13359602 14:27:23 (0xb3e74a...59fa7e), tx count: 36 miner 0x6ebaf477f83e055589c1188bcc6ddccd8c9b131a, sent by [Peer|eth66|13359602|Geth/v1.10.8-stable-0a420e61/linux-amd64/go1.16.8|51.158.155.8:30303] 
2021-10-05 14:27:30.0606|Could not find block 0x3e2cf2cb8b9c99d9e0cb0bbbde63a9d84b3b7988bd818feb35bed74962d212c0 
2021-10-05 14:27:30.0606|Could not find block 0xd36fa845c2d8dc0cd55ca5fd43a508b1d4189cf247d94de54309948135be2994 
2021-10-05 14:27:30.0606|Could not find block 0xd03ce600404e1d0de84fe07d28049dfbff0603d31ee0cb472a49f9e7e515f294 
2021-10-05 14:27:30.5651|Old Receipts   210569 / 13238000 | queue 43620 | current     0.00bps | total     0.00bps 
2021-10-05 14:27:30.5651|Downloaded 13358568 / 13359555 | current     0.00bps | total     0.22bps 
```

Once the receipt download started, the CPU usage spiked, and despite giving it 16 vCPUs and 32 GB memory, the receipt download seems to not progress beyond 210569 / 13238000 for several hours

I wonder how well this gp3 really works. I know from testing that in terms of IOPS hunger, Nethermind > Geth > Erigon. Can you test this again with a local NVMe volume and see how it goes?

The storage and transfer cost, btw, is why running nodes in AWS is expensive. Bare metal such as Hetzner or OVH works great and is a lot more affordable - but also doesn't have all the cloud management features that AWS has. It's a trade-off.

gp3 allows one to provision IOPS as per requirements. I have provisioned more IOPS than I did for geth, but I can give it more. 

Problem with using local NVMe on AWS is they are all non-persistent.

Do you know why the receipt download just gets stuck somewhere? Even if I increase the IOPS and restart the node from that point, it doesn't download a single old receipt even after running for two days.
OpenEthereum/v3.3.0-rc.8 removed GetNodeData, maybe we should disconnect them on mainnet?
Nodes syncs fine on our VM's. Currently high IOPS storage is needed, will be better when #2617 #3840  is delivered
